Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You can't show this to anyone.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You weren't even there. It's your truth. It's fiction.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You wanted him gone too. You sent him to me.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I told you it wouldn't work.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You've got to get me out of here. He nailed the windows shut while I was in the bath.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Dad didn't do that. I nailed the windows. Because you're not right.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You have to rest. Clear your head. Do you want to go back to Greystone?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: He wouldn't dare put me back there.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Were you even going to tell me you applied?!

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I didn't want her to know.  It was a dream anyway.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Trilling's there. Van Doren. English Professors. Important fellows. And New York City, right in your goddamn lap.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Love that is hoarded, molds at last.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Until we know, the only thing we have--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Is what we hand away. Have, hand. Consonance.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I wrote the goddamn poem. Go write your own.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Land of the fairies. Head there and you never come back.  Luke Detweiler, Danville, Virginia.

Speaker: tour guide
Dialogue: The South Hall library is a church, and these are the sacraments.

Speaker: tour guide
Dialogue: Original folios of the most important texts in history. Beowolf. First folio Hamlet. The Gutenberg Bible.

Speaker: tour
Dialogue: These are among the University's most prized possessions.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: On a Sunday afternoon, when the shutters are down and the proletariat possesses the street...

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: ...there are certain thoroughfares which remind one of nothing less...

Speaker: permissions librarian
Dialogue: Get down immediately. That book is restricted.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Which is why I committed it to memory.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Alert the press! Tell them Lucien Carr is innocent!

Speaker: tour guide
Dialogue: That was highly unusual. Campus is actually quite quiet. Moving on.

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: Rhyme, meter, conceit. Without this balance, a poem becomes slack, sloppy. An untucked shirt.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Professor Steeves, then how do you explain Whitman?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: He hated rhyme and meter. The whole point was untucking your shirt.

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: Ginsberg? Your father perhaps is the poet Louis Ginsberg?

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: He writes rhyming, metered verse. Why do you think he chose that form?

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: This university exists because of tradition and form. Would you rather this building be built by engineers or Whitman and his boys at play?

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: There can be no creation before imitation.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Shut the books. We're taking my brother with us to the social. He ships out tomorrow.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I can't. You see how much I've got to do.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: He's Navy. It's catnip for the skirts.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: You hymies are really all about work, huh?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Finally. An oasis in this wasteland.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: How come you're not at the social?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Only the most anti-social have to go to an event actually called one. Libation?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: How does a horrible bottle of Chianti sound?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Excellent. I love first times. I want my whole life to be composed of them. Life is only interesting if life is wide.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: To Walt Whitman, you dirty bastard.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: How's your Yeats? Have you read A Vision?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: It's completely brilliant and impossible. He says life is round: we're stuck on this wheel. Living. And dying.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: An endless circle. Until. Someone breaks it. You came in here, you rupture the pattern. Bang: the whole world...

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Are you a writer? Because I've got a job for a writer.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: He's trying to get inside my head.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Honey, I need you come home now.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: No, he's not here with me.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Listen, I'll come as soon as I can.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Welcome to the edge of the world.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: No, and I don't plan on it. She tasted like imported sophistication and domestic cigarettes.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Dave! Where's the liquor?! I'll be right back.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Artifacts in the visual field, some light-headedness. Motor hyperactivity.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Nitrous oxide, for narcoanalysis. Know thyself. And beshit thyself. Ever done that?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Oh no, thanks. I don't do...the cannabis.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Show me the man both sober and happy, and I'll show you the crinkled anus of a lying asshole.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Allen, Willy. Willy, Allen, Lucien reefer.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: He wishes he were a criminal. The Burroughs family is richer than God.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: He's a Harvard man, and he's going to be an amazing artist. His current medium is himself.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Bunk for school. Now, come on, I want you to meet our host.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: What there is, darlings and demoiselles, is a circle. Life is round. Patterns, routines, a wheel of self-abuse. Margaret, don't even deny it.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Until. The the disruption we long for, comes along and the circle is broken.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: He said he was my guardian angel, but that I was too much work.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Allen, who comes uninvited to my apartment.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: None of us notice him. Look at him. Why would we bother?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: So the pattern of our evening, our lives, holds. But under the right circumstances, even he might change the world.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: So you just met Lucien in the lunch line and now he's all that you can see.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Because David was in the same godforsaken line.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Some earjob at the bar just called me "boy." So I stole his drink.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: The best selling poet in the country.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: "A girl who is bespectacled. She may not get her nectacled. But safety pins and bassinets--"

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: And that's what he's selling?! I'll kill him.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: No. We're not going to kill him. Even better. We're going make sure nobody remembers him.  How many men started the Renaissance?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: More than I suspect this theory accommodates.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: We're sending millions to fight the Fascists in Europe, but they're here! Meter and rhyme---

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Yes! They're all guards in some prison. Let's make the prisoners come out and play. Let's come up with new words, new rhythms.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Tristan Tzara jabbed a knife into a dictionary.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: A literary revolution without writing a word. Neat trick, Lu.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: What about Yeats? How about the "New Vision?"

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: "In the dawn, armed with a burning patience, we shall enter the splendid city!"

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: It's Rimbaud. It's overwritten, I know. He's allowed.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: No, my mother. This is bad. This is very bad.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You don't understand. I have to.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Greystone will alert you if there's a change in her condition.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You can't do this to her.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I was out. With a friend.

Speaker: male nurse
Dialogue: It's time to go, Mrs. Ginsberg.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's for her best. It's not for my best. Look at her! Listen to her!

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: At least you have her. My father left me when I was four.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I've been thinking about what Yeats said. To be reborn, we have to die first.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I've spent my life making other people happy.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: It's time I find happiness the only way I see possible.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: If it be that I am indulging my self-consciousness in justifying myself, or if it be--

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Proclaims the death of morality. And...

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: The true, uninhibited, uncensored expression of the self.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: It's how we make the world wider.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Time slows down as you drift deeper and deeper into your cave...

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: We are exploring the avenues of Allen's mind.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Dimly-lit, I am sure. What have you done to my apartment?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: David, don't touch anything. We have to write it all down.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Get this man a pair of scissors!

Speaker: david
Dialogue: This is not your revolution, this is my life.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What kind of life is it?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: It's mine. Not everyone gets an allowance.  Leave. Get out!

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I need to speak to you. Alone.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You make me too smart, they're gonna suspect something's up.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: And get you sent back to your mother again? That would just be the end of you.

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: Your crushes, your juvenile metaphysics. None of them belong on the page. It is the first principle of good creative work. A work of fiction you will deliver as your final exam.

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: Oh look. Whitman Jr. graced us with his presence today.

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: "The New Vision. Extraordinary men propel us forward. It is our duty to break the law."  Fantastic.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: There's more life in those five pages than in the dozens of bad sonnets we've read in class.

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: You want life? You want the world on fire?

Speaker: professor steeves
Dialogue: The war awaits. What will it be?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: "The rose that scents the summer air/ grows from my beloved's hair...?"

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Keep going. That's my sonnet for Steeves.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: We have the map. We have the manifesto. We need the work.  I was wrong. Maybe you're not up for this after all.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Oh right, you don't have anything because David's not here to write it for you!

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: He's a professor working as a janitor so he can be near his precious Lu-Lu. He is a goddamn fruit who won't let me go.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Then let's get rid of him.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Right now, I just need you to write us something beautiful.  First thought, best thought.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: The Germans call it the "wonder drug." Prescribed for super-human feats.  Norman pops open a briefcase full of drugs. Bill selects a green pill bottle and gives it to Allen.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Sudden blindness, bouts of diarrhea, heart palpitations, and a severe decline in moral standards.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: But the words, oh the words...

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Ah. The "Vision" at last. Can I see?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: He's out. With a senior, some football player. A writer and handsome too.  James? Jack. There it is. Jack.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You're not allowed to be here.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: That's odd since I'm the only thing keeping him here.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Piece of advice. You don't know Lu. As soon you think you do, he'll find someone else.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: I found a real writer. Already a million words under his belt before Columbia.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: What am I supposed to do? Newsreels?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: If you're going to stay, don't hog the blanket.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Why is Jack a real writer?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Once you meet him, you'll see what I mean.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: What do you think? Brilliant, no?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: It's missing some periods and commas.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: It's better than anything you've ever written.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: My best friend since I was twelve. Off in the Navy.

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: I didn't know we were having guests.

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: Out? I cooked all day for you.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What do you want me to do? Eat shoe leather? I'm hungry and what you do in the kitchen is unholy.

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: That's funny. You talk like a Catholic. But you fuck me and won't marry me. How does that work?

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: I thought you liked it WIDE OPEN...

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: So Al. You thought my novel was shit?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: It's all true. Jack served in the Merchant Marines.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I've left school twice already. Columbia's full of squares. I'm not even sure why I bothered to come back.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Then why don't you just ship out again?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Trust me. Sometimes when I fight with Edie, I want to.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Sounds phony. Movements are cooked up by people who can't write about the people who can.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Lu, I don't think he gets what we're trying to do.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Listen to me, this whole town's full of finks on the 30th floor, writing pure chintz. Writers, real writers, gotta be in the beds. In the trenches. In all the broken places. What're your trenches, Al?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Fuck you. What does that even mean?!

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Be careful. You are not in wonderland I have heard the strange madness long growing in your soul. But you are fortunate.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: In your ignorance In your isolation, you who have suffered Find where love hides. Give. Share. Lose. Lest we die unbloomed.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Forget Columbia. Forget Ogden Nash. Here's the plan, boys. We join the Merchant Marines. Sail the world until the war ends. Then jump ship and make it to Paris. For the liberation.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Jack does. It'll be us, together. At the beginning. It'll be the perfect day.

Speaker: police officer
Dialogue: Put your hands in the air!

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: Your attendance record here is abominable. You've ignored curfew. Your papers, when you bother to turn them in, exceed the assigned page limit. Can you explain why you're at Columbia?

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: I know about your difficulties. About what happened in Chicago.

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: See, the University acts in loco parentis. You are our responsibility. We're trying to find someway to make this all work.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Who said anybody could know anything about anything?!

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: So that's why you locked mom up.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Did he put you up to this?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: No. I stole the boat. And it was tremendous.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You know me now. I'm only good at beginnings.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: My father shows up yesterday with some new woman. And in the middle of the Allen's-a-screw-up monologue, all of a sudden, I realize: I don't care. I've never not cared. So, I told them it was my idea. To steal the boat.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Because I don't want to be the person they think I am. I'm on academic probation. I could be kicked out. You can't leave. You started something and I have no idea what I'm supposed to do next.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: It's our turn. Let's show them what we can do.

Speaker: permissions librarian
Dialogue: You must not drink while you're handling it. And no writing in it.

Speaker: permissions librarian
Dialogue: It must come back exactly as you found it.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I see you checking out all these books. And I'm asking myself: do you ever get checked out?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I wondered if you could help me.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: Okay. Does this book have a title?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: It's called The Day Amanda Came.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: Well, you'll have to wait. I can't leave the desk.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Working here must be a drag.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: I like it. It's the only way I meet boys. They're very strict at Barnard.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: For example, they'd never let me do this.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: Did you know I've never done it with someone who was Jewish before? I really want to know what it looks like.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I thought you were saying something but not saying it. Should we find your book?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: There is no book. Take it off.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: It's not like I'm a virgin. I've done it with three guys already. You're a virgin, huh?

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: You're kind of a virgin, though, huh?

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: Liar. If you have done it before, you'll last for thirty seconds. Start counting.

Speaker: gwendolyn
Dialogue: I bet you don't even read.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Excuse me. I think I saw some light or movement in the library.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What the hell, Bill? It's locked!

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Lu that's enough. Come on! What's wrong with you?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: No. Not yet, we have to finish.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Get off of me! Allen! Help!

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Open the goddamn door! Open this up!

Speaker: tour guide
Dialogue: The South Hall library is a church, and these are the sacraments.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Yep. Last year. They still won.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Souvenir history. To make people think they left some mark on the world. Because otherwise nobody would ever know.  I don't ever want to end up on this wall.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Have no fear. You never will.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Since you didn't show up earlier, I just hoped to give you this.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Maybe he didn't want to see you.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I think he can speak for himself.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Yup. And he says we should all have another round...

Speaker: david
Dialogue: You've had plenty of time to celebrate. Your library hijink made the morning paper. I'm sure you're all very proud.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: How did you know it was us?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Did he use that "Bastille" line? Cause I gave it to him.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: I haven't seen you for days.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: You left this at my place.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You told the guards we were there. No one else knew.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You wanted me to get kicked out?! You ratted on me!

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Stop, Lu. You're losing control again. You know what comes next. I know what comes next.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: You said I was everything to you. You are everything to me. Everything to me. Do you hear me?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Let's go. Time and place, David.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: You'd be dead if it weren't for me!

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You'd be boring if it weren't for me!

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Jack? Jack?  He broke his fucking neck. The warrior poet has passed on.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: This is just the beginning, you know.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Your fault, Ginsy. It's all your fault.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: No. Allen's got work to do. Ten pages on Spengler's Decline of the West. Due tomorrow.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: I'd be lost without you, Ginsy.  Come on, Lion.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Lu's going to use the loo.

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: We invited her over for her birthday. We made her a cake.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Then we should have a drink! How about a drink, Grandma Frankie? You want some red wine?

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: Where the hell have you been?!

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: I packed all your stuff. It's in your bag. I'm going to be at Gram's tonight.

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: You just say that, but it's one of your million words and they don't mean anything!  Just don't be here when I come back in the morning.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I know this is crazy. I don't know even know what I'm doing here. But I had to tell you I'm sorry. Let me make it up to you.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: I'm going back to bed. Another word and I call the police.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: We've got to make a ship, probably as merchant seamen. Jack knows the tricks.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You weren't going to tell me?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: We both know why you can't come.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Fuck you. You're a phony. You got me and Jack and Bill making your vision come true. All because you couldn't do it yourself.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: No, you got what you wanted. You were ordinary, just like every other freshman, and I made your life extraordinary. Go be you now, all by yourself. Leave me alone.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Allen, have you seen him? He's not in his room.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I did something wrong. Really wrong. And you have no reason to help me. But

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I know who you are. We're the ones he needs, but never wants. It hurts, doesn't it?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: All I am asking is tell me where he is. Please.

Speaker: billeting officer
Dialogue: Go upstairs to get on the docket.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Let's go get on the docket.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: How did you know I would be here?!

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Listen, I spoke to a guy upstairs. I got two passes. I packed for both of us. We can leave.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: The reason I'm leaving is you.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Then you and Jack take them. I'll catch up.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Come with me. We're taking a walk.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Could I have a whiskey, please?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: He didn't come back here afterwards. Nobody on the floor saw.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: We have two in custody. We're still getting names.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: So what do we know about this Carr kid? Did we have any friends? We're gonna have to speak to all of them.

Speaker: edie
Dialogue: The police took him down to the Tombs. As an accessory. Bill too.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: He wanted to hurt me, I had no choice.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: You could have run. Called the police.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: Listen. Somehow he found me at the Marine Hall.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: He said no matter where I went, he would follow. When I confronted him, he exploded. I had to defend myself. He wouldn't stop.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: But how did Jack and Bill get roped into this?

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: The D.A. is asking for my deposition. In writing.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: We both know I can't do it. I don't know what I'm going to do. I'm going to be stuck in here for the rest of my life!

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: We're going to say it was an "honor slaying".

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Dad. It's five thousand dollars for bail. I know it's a lot--

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Would you all just SHUT THE HELL UP?!

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: You must understand David has been following him for years.

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: When Lucien went to Bowdoin, David appeared out of thin air. So I sent Lu to Chicago.

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: Surprise, David turned up there too. Then, when Lucien wanted to go to Mexico, guess who had a car idling in the driveway?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: But he didn't have to go with him.

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: He spun a web to ensnare my son. That's why I brought him here. A lot of good that did.

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: Thank God Lu has you in his life. He talks about you all the time.

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: You know what Allen? He calls you his guardian angel.

Speaker: marion carr
Dialogue: That man ruined my son. You're going to help me keep what's left of him.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Contrary to reports, prison is not a tonic for the spirit.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: All the district attorney cared about was if David was queer.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: And what did you tell them?

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: Did David do something Lu in Chicago?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Christ Allen, please don't get involved.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I have to be. I'm helping him write his defense.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: David was my friend. But he's dead. And did Lucien tell you how he died?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: The libertine circle has come to an end.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: He would leave me alone in the house. I was going to die there.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hey, I'm okay now. I'm your mother. And I'm okay.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I'm in over my head. Someone I know killed a man. And I don't know what to do. He wants my help. And I don't know if I should give it to him. I don't know if it's right. It's just a mess.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Let him go. Don't help him.

Speaker: allen
Dialogue: I can't, mom. He's my best friend.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: The most important thing your father ever did was fail me.  You understand?

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Let's get out of the city. Anywhere you want. I've saved up.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: I was just a kid, you dragged me into your perverted mess!

Speaker: david
Dialogue: How can you say that? You know that's not true.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: I will never give up on us.

Speaker: david
Dialogue: Now I know how you felt.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You can't show this to anyone.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You weren't even there. It's your truth. It's fiction.

Speaker: lucien
Dialogue: You wanted him gone too. You sent him to me.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: He'll be with you in a minute. Please, have a seat.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Mr. Ginsberg. He's ready for you.

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: No, please tell me. Professor Steeves says you submitted it as your final.

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: Well, then, let me tell you. It is smutty and absurd.

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: You've taken incompletes in two classes. And you are already on academic probation. There are rules you agreed to upon admittance into this university. And you have managed to break and keep breaking them. You don't seem to have much respect for this institution. So you may either retract this fiction as your final. Or you may choose to be expelled. What will it be?
